|area percentage = 25.23% |census yr = 2010 |pop = 916,829 |density_km2 = 565.5

|ex image = DarienCTGorhamBridge09012007.jpg |ex image cap = Rings End Bridge,
in Darien }}

'Fairfield County' is the southwestern-most and most densely populated county of
the U.S. state of Connecticut. The county has a population of 916,829 according
to the 2010 Census, giving a density of 1,465 people per square mile. The county
contains four of the state's largest cities (Bridgeport (1st), Stamford (4th),
Norwalk (6th) and Danbury (7th)) whose combined population of 433,368 is almost
half the county's. [http://2010.census.gov/2010census/data/index.php
] The United States Office of Management and Budget has designated
Fairfield County as the Bridgeport-Stamford-Norwalk, CT Metropolitan Statistical
Area. As a result of commuter interchange, it is also
part of the New York-Newark-Bridgeport, NY-NJ-CT-PA Combined Statistical Area.

Fairfield County's Gold Coast helps rank it sixth in the US in per-capita
personal income by the Bureau of Economic Analysis in 2005, See 
contributing substantially to Connecticut being one of the most affluent states
in the US. [http://ccee.uconn.edu/Connecticut%20--
%20HOW%20UNEQUAL%20IS%20CT%20INCOME.pdf The Connecticut Economy Fall 2008]

In addition to its wealthy communities, Fairfield County is also home to lower-
middle and working class-cities. Other communities are more densely populated
and economically diverse than the affluent areas for which the county is
better known.

As is the case with all eight of Connecticut's counties, there is no county
government and no county seat. As an area it is only a geographical point of
reference. In Connecticut the cities and towns are responsible for all local
governmental activities including fire and rescue, schools, and snow removal; in
a few cases, neighboring towns will share certain resources.
categories: Counties in the New York metropolitan area
